perturbation.original_text: 1. California Business and Professions Code Sections 20000 through 20043 provide rights to you concerning termination or non-renewal of a franchise. If the Master Franchise Agreement contains provisions that are inconsistent with the law, the law will control.
perturbation.changed_text: 1. The Master Franchise Agreement governs termination or non-renewal of a franchise.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the reference to California Business and Professions Code Sections 20000 through 20043 and the statement that California law will control, the modified text implies that the Master Franchise Agreement is the sole authority on franchise termination and non-renewal. This contradicts any implied clause in the agreement where it says that external laws will take precedence over this agreement.

perturbation.original_text: 6. The Master Franchise Agreement requires non-binding mediation. The mediation will occur in New York with the costs being borne by equally by the parties. Prospective franchisees are encouraged to consult private legal counsel to determine the applicability of California and federal laws (such as Business and Professions Code Section 20040.5 and Code of Civil Procedure Section 1281) to any provisions of a franchise agreement restricting venue to a forum outside the State of California.
perturbation.changed_text: 6. The Master Franchise Agreement requires mediation. The mediation will occur in New York with the costs being borne equally by the parties.
perturbation.explanation: Removing the word 'non-binding' creates ambiguity. Later, if another section says the agreement is fully compliant with California Law, but the binding agreement isn't, there will be confusion.

perturbation.original_text: 8. You must sign a general release if you renew or transfer your franchise. California Corporation Code 31512 voids a waiver of your rights under the Franchise Investment Law (California Corporations Code 31000 through 31516). Business and Professions Code 20010 voids a waiver of your rights under the Franchise Relations Act (Business and Professions Code 20000 through 20043).
perturbation.changed_text: 8. You must sign a general release if you renew or transfer your franchise.
perturbation.explanation: By removing references to California Corporation Code 31512 and Business and Professions Code 20010, the text removes the explicit protection against waiving rights under California law. This introduces an ambiguity if the master agreement has an implied 'Full compliance with CA state law' clause, but it says signing the release is mandatory.
